--- name: Technical Planning Session description: Comprehensive technical planning and architecture review process version: 1.0 duration: 2-4 hours participants: [tech-lead, senior-developers, product-owner] ---
# Technical Planning Workflow
## Pre-Planning (30 minutes) - Review product requirements and user stories - Analyze technical constraints and dependencies - Prepare architecture diagrams and technical documentation - Identify potential technical risks and challenges
## Planning Session (90-180 minutes)
### 1. Requirements Analysis (30 minutes) - Walk through functional and non-functional requirements - Clarify technical acceptance criteria - Identify integration points and external dependencies - Discuss performance and scalability requirements
### 2. Architecture Design (60-120 minutes) - Design system architecture and component interactions - Define API contracts and data models - Select appropriate technology stack and frameworks - Plan database schema and data migration strategy - Design security and authentication mechanisms
### 3. Implementation Strategy (30-60 minutes) - Break down work into implementable tasks - Estimate effort and identify critical path - Plan development phases and milestones - Define testing strategy and quality gates - Assign initial task ownership
### 4. Risk Assessment (15 minutes) - Identify technical risks and mitigation strategies - Plan proof-of-concept tasks for uncertain areas - Document assumptions and constraints - Create contingency plans for high-risk items
## Post-Planning (15 minutes) - Document all decisions and rationale - Create technical tickets with detailed specifications - Share architecture diagrams with the team - Schedule follow-up sessions if needed
## Deliverables - Technical architecture document - API specifications and contracts - Database design and migration plan - Task breakdown with effort estimates - Risk register with mitigation plans

--- name: Feature Development Workflow description: Test-driven development process for new features version: 1.0 duration: 1-5 days participants: [developer, tech-lead, qa-engineer] ---
# Feature Development Workflow
## 1. Requirements Analysis (30 minutes) - Review user story and acceptance criteria - Clarify requirements with product owner if needed - Understand integration points and dependencies - Plan implementation approach and timeline
## 2. Technical Design (60 minutes) - Design component architecture and data flow - Plan API endpoints and data models - Create wireframes or mockups for UI changes - Document technical approach and decisions
## 3. Test Planning (30 minutes) - Write test scenarios based on acceptance criteria - Plan unit tests for core business logic - Design integration tests for API endpoints - Consider edge cases and error conditions
## 4. Implementation (1-4 days) ### Test-Driven Development Cycle: - Write failing test for next functionality - Implement minimal code to make test pass - Refactor code while keeping tests green - Repeat until feature is complete
### Development Tasks: - Implement backend API endpoints with validation - Create database migrations if needed - Build frontend components and user interface - Add error handling and loading states - Write comprehensive test coverage
## 5. Quality Assurance (2-4 hours) - Run full test suite and fix any failures - Perform manual testing of new functionality - Test integration with existing features - Verify performance and accessibility standards - Check responsive design on multiple devices
## 6. Code Review (1-2 hours) - Create pull request with detailed description - Include screenshots or demo videos for UI changes - Address feedback from code reviewers - Ensure CI/CD pipeline passes all checks
## 7. Deployment (30 minutes) - Deploy to staging environment for final testing - Coordinate with QA team for acceptance testing - Deploy to production following release process - Monitor application health and error rates - Document any deployment notes or rollback procedures
## Deliverables - Fully tested and reviewed code changes - Updated documentation and API specifications - Test coverage report and quality metrics - Demo video or screenshots of new functionality

--- name: Daily Standup Meeting description: 15-minute team synchronization and blocker identification version: 1.0 duration: 15 minutes participants: [scrum-master, tech-lead, developer, qa-engineer, product-owner] ---
# Daily Standup Workflow
## Pre-Meeting Setup (2 minutes) - Ensure all team members can attend or have provided async updates - Review previous day's commitments and current sprint board - Prepare any relevant metrics or information to share - Set up video call and screen sharing if remote
## Standup Meeting (12 minutes)
### Round Robin Updates (8-10 minutes) Each team member shares: 1. **Yesterday**: What did you complete yesterday? 2. **Today**: What do you plan to work on today? 3. **Blockers**: Any impediments preventing progress?
### Follow-up Discussions (2-4 minutes) - Address any quick questions or clarifications - Identify who needs to connect after the standup - Note any blockers requiring immediate attention - Confirm sprint goal alignment and progress
## Post-Meeting Actions (1 minute) - Update sprint board with any status changes - Schedule follow-up conversations for complex issues - Add impediments to tracking system - Send summary to stakeholders if needed
## Meeting Guidelines - Keep individual updates to 1-2 minutes maximum - Focus on work, not personal details - Save detailed technical discussions for after standup - Encourage team members to ask for help - Maintain positive and supportive atmosphere
## Red Flags to Address - Team members consistently missing standups - Updates becoming status reports to management - Technical discussions derailing the meeting - Same blockers mentioned repeatedly - Lack of collaboration and communication

--- name: Sprint Planning Session description: Collaborative planning session to define sprint goals and commitments version: 1.0 duration: 4-8 hours (2-week sprint) participants: [scrum-master, tech-lead, developer, qa-engineer, product-owner] ---
# Sprint Planning Workflow
## Part 1: What can we deliver? (2-4 hours)
### Sprint Goal Definition (30 minutes) - Review product roadmap and business priorities - Define clear, measurable sprint goal - Ensure goal aligns with team capacity and skills - Get commitment from product owner and team
### Backlog Refinement (60-90 minutes) - Review top priority items from product backlog - Ensure user stories meet Definition of Ready - Clarify acceptance criteria and business value - Identify dependencies and integration points - Update story estimates if needed
### Capacity Planning (30 minutes) - Review team availability for the sprint - Account for holidays, training, and meetings - Consider previous sprint velocity trends - Factor in any known impediments or risks
### Story Selection (60-120 minutes) - Select stories that align with sprint goal - Ensure total estimate fits within team capacity - Prioritize stories by business value - Consider technical dependencies and risks - Get team consensus on sprint commitment
## Part 2: How will we deliver? (2-4 hours)
### Technical Planning (90-150 minutes) - Break down selected stories into technical tasks - Identify implementation approaches and patterns - Plan integration and testing strategies - Assign initial task ownership - Estimate task effort in hours
### Definition of Done Review (15 minutes) - Confirm Definition of Done criteria - Update criteria if processes have changed - Ensure everyone understands quality standards - Plan for quality assurance activities
### Risk Assessment (30 minutes) - Identify potential impediments and risks - Plan mitigation strategies - Create backup plans for high-risk items - Document assumptions and dependencies
### Sprint Backlog Finalization (15 minutes) - Finalize sprint backlog with all tasks - Set up tracking in project management tool - Schedule any additional planning sessions needed - Confirm team commitment to sprint goal
## Deliverables - Clear and measurable sprint goal - Prioritized sprint backlog with estimates - Task breakdown with initial assignments - Updated team capacity and velocity metrics - Risk register with mitigation plans - Sprint tracking dashboard setup
## Success Criteria - Team has high confidence in meeting sprint goal - All stories meet Definition of Ready - Technical approach is clearly defined - Risks and dependencies are identified - Team commitment is explicit and realistic
